clean_content:
Definition / general

* Accumulation of carbon in lymph nodes, more commonly in intrapulmonary lymph nodes, due to coal dust, smoke or pollution* May be associated with storiform pattern of histiocytes that resembles a neoplasm ([Hum Pathol 1998;29:851](9712428))* Associated with silica, although often no history of industrial exposure* Associated with hyalinization in nodes of elderly Japanese ([Histol Histopathol 2003;18:1169](12973685))

Sites

* Common in hilar and bronchial lymph nodes

Clinical features

* Enlargement of involved lymph nodes, prominent mediastinal lymphadenopathy is common

Radiology description

* Enlarged lymph nodes, especially mediastinal and bronchial lymph nodes

Radiology images

*Images hosted on other servers:*  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodesanthracosisthumbimg01.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2910103/figure/f1/)

Apical lung lesion

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodesanthracosisthumbimg02.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2910103/figure/f2/)

Increased uptake in left upper lobe

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodesanthracosisthumbimg03.jpg)](http://origin-ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2213007113000385-gr1.jpg)

FDG PET/CT scan shows  
high-grade metabolic activity  
in right hilar soft tissue lesion

Prognostic factors

* Benign process with no significant clinical implications

Case reports

* 71 year old woman, with life-long exposure to soot from a wood cook stove, with anthracosis and large mediastinal mass with healed pulmonary tuberculosis ([Clin Med Res 2010;8:99](20660934))* Women who cooked over wood fires, with primary nodal anthracosis identified as a cause of FDG PET/CT positive mediastinal lymphadenopathy ([Respiratory Medicine Case Reports 2013;10:48](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2213007113000385))* A case of anthracosis presenting with mediastinal lymph nodes mimicking tuberculous lymphadenitis or malignancy ([Eur J Intern Med 2003;14:444](14614980))

Treatment

* If significant enlargement, excision biopsy

Gross description

* Enlarged lymph nodes with firm dark brown to black cut surfaces

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Anthracotic macrophages in clusters and singly dispersed* There may be storiform arrangement of spindle cells or granuloma like aggregates of macrophages* Fine anthracotic pigment* Also nodal hyaline scars and polarizable material suggestive of silica

Cytology description

* Cellular smears with a population of anthracotic macrophages that are both singly dispersed and in variously sized aggregates* Variable foreign body type, multinucleated giant cells* No necrosis or atypical cells

Cytology images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodesanthracosis_ars.els-cdn04.jpg)](http://origin-ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2213007113000385-gr3.jpg)

Abundant anthracotic pigment

Differential diagnosis

* Clinically resembles malignancy: lymphoma, metastasis* [Follicular dendritic cell tumor](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesFDCsarcoma.html)* [Kaposi sarcoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/softtissuekaposi.html)* [MFH](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/softtissuemfhpleo.html)* [Sarcoidosis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lungnontumorsarcoidosis.html)* [Spindle cell melanoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skintumormelanocyticmelanoma.html)* [Tuberculosis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesotherinfections.html#tuberculosis)

Additional references

* [J Korean Med Sci 2013;28:550](23580351), [Ann Nucl Med Sci 2004;17:105](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/242241161_False_Positive_18F-FDG_Uptake_in_Mediastinal_Lymph_Nodes_for_a_Patient_with_Pulmonary_Adenocarcinoma_A_Case_Report), [AJR Am J Roentgenol 2000;174:523](10658734)
